text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised 4.13.1 Audit Reconsideration, Introduction.
IRM 4.13.1.2 - Added clarifying content.
This material supersedes IRM 4.13.1, dated 12–31–2009. The IPUs have been incorporated into the IRM.

) These procedures are directed at: a. Ensuring the amount of assessed tax is correct. b. Ensuring the collection process is suspended while the reconsideration request is being considered. c. Ensuring that the procedures support the abatement of assessments in appropriate situations. d. Ensuring that cases are handled in a consistent manner. (

) An audit reconsideration is the process the IRS uses to reevaluate the of a prior audit where additional tax was assessed and remains unpaid, or a an Audit tax credit was reversed. If the taxpayer disagrees with the original tion he/she must provide new information for the audited issue(s) that was previously considered during the original examination. It is also the process IRS uses when the taxpayer contests a substitute for return (SFR) tion by filing an original delinquent return or when there is a n IRS computational or processing error in assessing the tax. Please see IRM
, Policy Statement
(Formerly P-

) Some reasons for an audit reconsideration request: a. The taxpayer did not appear for the audit. a Request b. The taxpayer moved and did not receive the correspondence from the IRS. c. The taxpayer has new documentation pertinent to audited issue(s) to present. (

) A taxpayer might request an audit reconsideration if: a. The taxpayer disagrees with an audit assessment from an audit of return. b. The taxpayer disagrees with an assessment created under the authority IRC
(b), Substitute for Return (SFR). c. The taxpayer has been denied tax credits such as earned income credit (EITC) claimed, during prior examination. (

) In order to request an audit reconsideration: a. The taxpayer must have filed a tax return. b. The assessment remains unpaid or the Service has reversed tax credits that the taxpayer is disputing. c. The taxpayer must identify which adjustments he/she is disputing. d. The taxpayer must provide new additional information for the audited issue(s) not considered during the original examination. e. There was an IRS computational or processing error in assessing the (

) Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) helps taxpayers whose problems with the IRS are causing financial difficulties; who have tried but haven’t been able resolve problems with the IRS; and those who believe an IRS system or procedure isn’t working as it should. TAS accepts cases based on the TAS criteria outlined in IRM
, TAS Case Criteria. In general, suffering an economic burden (TAS criteria
), immediate threat of action, significant costs, irreparable injury, or a significant systematic delay (TAS criteria
) meet TAS criteria. TAS criteria might exist at any point in (
) Internal Revenue Manual
meet TAS criteria
AND involve identity theft. Applicable cases will now considered IPSU criteria. See IRM
, Identity Theft, for additional mation. (
) TAS Audit Reconsideration Procedures for referring TAS cases. Supporting documentation attached to Form
, Operations Assistance Request (OAR), should include new information for the audited issue(s) that was not considered during the original examination. In addition, Form
must also include the following information if it is not already available on RGS:
Request (OAR), should include new information for the audited issue(s) that was not considered during the original examination. In addition, Form

must also include the following information if it is not already available on RGS: a. Any information received from the taxpayer pertinent to the examination issue, b. Copies of letters and reports received by the taxpayer from the IRS, if available, c. Copies of documents already submitted by the taxpayer, if available, or, d. Amended returns, if applicable. Note: On examinations conducted in an area office, the administrative files must provided to resolve the audit reconsideration. If unable to obtain the trative file, the Report Generating Software (RGS) information should be requested from the appropriate SBSE RGS Coordinator. On examinations conducted in a campus, examiners should attempt to resolve audit eration requests by using Correspondence Examination Automation (CEAS) information, whenever possible. The administrative file may be requested by TAS, if RGS information is not available or is not sufficient to resolve the request. (
) Review the special instructions TAS has entered on Form

. TAS will identify cases that require expedite processing. These cases must be within one workday and completed in three days. Cases not identified as expedite must be assigned within three work days and completed within
days. The Tax Examiner Assistant has
days to renegotiate OAR dates. (

) All TAS cases must be worked in adherence with the Service Level Agree- ments and addenda between W&I, SB/SE, and TAS. See TAS web site for Service Level Agreements at http://tas.web.irs.gov/policy/sla/default.aspx or the internet at Agreements-(SLAs) (
) The Internal Revenue Service has the discretionary authority to abate an sessment of any tax if it is excess of the taxpayer’s liability per IRC
(a) and Treas. Reg
) A request for reconsideration will be considered if:

a. Any information received from the taxpayer pertinent to the examination issue, b. Copies of letters and reports received by the taxpayer from the IRS, if available, c. Copies of documents already submitted by the taxpayer, if available, or, d. Amended returns, if applicable.

) A request for reconsideration will not be considered if: a. The taxpayer has already been afforded an audit reconsideration of and did not provide any additional information with his/her current that would change the audit results. b. The assessment was made as a result of a closing agreement entered into under IRC
using Form
Closing Agreements on Final mination Covering Specific Matters or Form
Agreement as to Final Determination of Tax Liability, or some combination of the two forms. c. The assessment was made as a result of a compromise under IRC Section

These agreements are final and conclusive. A final mise determination can be identified on IDRS by the posting of a TC d. The assessment was made as the result of final TEFRA administrative proceedings. e. The assessment was made as a result of the taxpayer entering into an agreement on Form

-AD, Offer to Waive Restrictions on Assessment and Collection of Tax Deficiency and to Accept Overassessment. f. The United States Tax Court has entered a decision that has become or a District Court or the United States Court of Federal Claims has rendered a judgment on the merits that has become final. g. The United States Tax Court has dismissed a case for lack of Note: Any request for reconsideration on cases that were settled by Tax Court, District Court, or Court of Federal Claims should be forwarded to the of the Associate Area Counsel for forwarding to the docket attorney. Note: A case dismissed by a court for lack of jurisdiction can be reconsidered if conditions for acceptance are met. When the Tax Court dismisses a case lack of jurisdiction, it does not enter a decision and the case is not on the merits. See IRC Section
(d). Likewise, when a District Court or the United States Court of Federal Claims dismisses a case for lack of diction, the case has not been dismissed on the merits. (

zone during the original audit (plus 180 days after leaving the combat zone), reverse all assessments made by Exam. Review of the taxpayer’s account will show a TC 500 with closing codes 52, 54 and 56 that provides the entry and exit dates within the combat zone. The account also have a –C freeze. Refer to IRM 5.19.10.6.3 , Combat Zone Freeze Code and IRM 4.4.1-9, Combat Zone Procedures, for further information. b. Normal combat zone procedures IRM 4.19.13.20 , Combat Zone, do not apply to reconsideration cases, where the tax year(s) in question was not the same year(s) that the taxpayer was in a combat zone (plus 180 days after leaving the combat zone). For reconsideration requests other than
the year(s) that combat zone procedures apply, continue to work and cor- respond with the taxpayer to resolve the reconsideration request.
Disaster Case Special procedures apply to disaster situations. Refer to IRM 25.16.1, Program Guidelines, for guidance issued specific to the disaster.
